Hydrogen spillover phenomenon can significantly impact the activity in hydrogenation reaction, but the spillover is limited in a very short range on non-reducible Al2O3, a most widely used industrial support. Herein, Al2O3 doped with different lanthanides (ln) was prepared by co-precipitation, which was then used to produce Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts. These catalysts display much higher hydrogenation activity towards alkylated anthraquinone than undoped Pd/Al2O3 catalyst and those modified by non-lanthanide elements. After the introduction of lanthanides, the reaction order of H2 decreases from 1 to 0. Further characterization and DFT calculation show that H2 storage ability is increased for ln-doped catalysts due to the low activation energy of H transfer and low adsorption energy of H on O(-ln) sites. In addition, a reasonable relationship between reducibility of ln3+ in catalysts and the catalytic performance is found. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalyst Hydrogenation Adjacent O(-ln) site H storage Reducibility Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide, a green chemical which is widely used in chemical industry, [1 , 2] is manufactured on an industrial scale by the anthraquinone process, with Pd/Al2O3 being the most commonly used hydrogenation catalyst. [3] Prior to hydrogenation, both of the reactants, namely alkylated anthraquinone (AQ) and H2, should be adsorbed and activated on the surface of Pd nanoparticles. [4] The inevitable competitive adsorption among AQ, H2 and the product hydrogenated AQ (AQH) would limit the total reaction rate, and therefore should be alleviated. Many attempts have been made to solve the problem by changing the electronic and geometric properties of Pd through the introduction of a second metal element. It is reported that the incorporation of Ru [5], Co and Ag [6] could create Pd-Mδ+ sites, which strengthen the adsorption of C=O in AQ molecules, increasing the catalytic performance. Moreover, the introduction of Ir [7] could decrease the size of Pd NPs and isolate continuous Pd sites, thus increasing the amounts of active sites. Both effects have been found over Ga [8 , 9], Fe, Ni and Mn [10] doped catalysts. However, instead of solving competitive adsorption, these modifications mainly focus on tuning the ratio of adsorbed AQ molecules to dissociated H or increasing the number of active sites in catalysts by improving Pd dispersion. Hydrogen spillover is a potential way to solve the problem. H atoms could easily spill over on the reducible materials, such as TiO2 and CeO2, [11 , 12] but spillover is limited in a very short range on non-reducible supports such as Al2O3, [13] which unfortunately is the most widely used support for the AQ hydrogenation catalyst. It is previously reported that Pd/La-Al2O3 could reversibly store and release H atoms dissociated by Pd NPs at adjacent O(-La) sites. [14] In this study, more lanthanide-doped Al2O3 and corresponding Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts have been prepared to better understand the underlying mechanism. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Al2(SO4)3·18H2O, NaAlO2, PdCl2 and NaCl were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Gd(NO3)3·6H2O. Sm(NO3)3·6H2O, Pr(NO3)3·6H2O, Nd(NO3)3·6H2O, Mn(NO3)2·6H2O, (NH3)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, 2-ethyl-anthraquinone (2-EAQ), 1,2,4-trimethyl benzene (1,2,4-TMB) and tetrabutylurea (TBU) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All of these chemicals were of analytical purity and used without further purification. 2.2 Support preparation Pseudo boehmites doped with different kinds of elements were synthesized by co-precipitation. To be specific, Al2(SO4)3 and lanthanide or other elements were dissolved in 100 ml of deionized water to form solution A, in which c(Al) and c(ln) are 0.54 mol·L−1 and 0.18 mol·L−1, respectively; NaAlO2 was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water to obtain solution B, in which c(Al) is 1.68 mol·L−1. 50 mL of deionized water was added into a 500-ml rounded-flask and heated to 70°C, into which solution A and solution B were pumped at the rate of around 8.0 mL·min−1 and under vigorous stirring. After addition, the obtained white slurry was aged at the same temperature for another one hour. The aged slurry was centrifugated and the remaining cake was washed by deionized water several times until the pH decreased to around 7. The washed cake was dried in an oven at the temperature of 90°C overnight and then calcinated at the temperature of 960°C for 4 hours to obtain modified Al2O3. Pure Al2O3 was synthesized by the same method without the addition of other chemicals. 2.3 Catalyst preparation PdCl2 powder and NaCl with molar ratio at 1:2 were dissolved in deionized water at room temperature to obtain Na2PdCl4 solution. Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/modified-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation, in which the Pd loading was fixed at 1.5 wt%. After adsorption for an hour, the samples were consequently washed with deionized water until no Cl— could be detected, dried at 120°C for 8 h, and calcinated at 450°C for 4 h. 2.4 Catalytic tests The catalytic performance was assessed by conducting the hydrogenation of 2-EAQ in a 100-mL Teflon-lined magnetic stirring reactor. The stirring speed, hydrogen pressure, and temperature were set at 1000 r·min−1, 0.30 MPa, and 40°C, respectively. The working solution consisted of 2-EAQ, 1,2,4-TMB and TBU, in which the concentration of 2-EAQ was 120 g·L−1 and the volume ratio of 1,2,4-TMB to TBU was 3:2. In a typical run, 25 mg of catalyst and 60.0 mL working solution were introduced into the reactor. After reaction, 5 mL of hydrogenated working solution was taken, filtered to remove catalyst, and subsequently oxidized prior to extraction using deionized water. The concentration of extracted hydrogen peroxide aqueous solution could be determined through potassium permanganate titration. The catalytic performance was quantified as the mass of hydrogen peroxide present in a unit volume of the hydrogenated working solution, which could be calculated by the following formula: η = 5 2 × C × V × M V 0 where η is the concentration of produced H2O2 in oxidized working solution (g·L−1), C is the concentration of KMnO4 solution (around 0.02 mol·L−1), V is the volume of consumed KMnO4 solution, V0 is the volume of the oxidized working solution (5.00 mL), and M is the relative molecular mass of H2O2 (34.02 g·mol−1). 2.5 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffractometer test was operated by Shimadzu XRD-600 with Cu Kα radiation (scanning range was 20 ∼ 80° with a step size of 0.02°). Elemental analysis for Pd and lanthanides was measured using an Agilent 7800 inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (ICP-MS). The samples have been dissolved thoroughly in aqua regia acid solution before test. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were carried out on a Micrometrics Gemini VII2390 analyzer at -196°C. Prior to the measurements, the samples were outgassed at 300°C with a vacuum degree of 100 mTorr for 6 h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method were used to determine the surface area and pore size distribution of samples, respectively, and total volume of pore was measured at P/P 0 = 0.99. 27Al magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (27Al MAS NMR) was carried out on the solid-state nuclear magnetic spectrometer (Bruker 400WB AVANCE Ⅲ) to determine the coordination structure of Al3+. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on a JEOL JEM-2100F high-resolution transmission electron microscope. The mean diameter of Pd nanoparticles was determined by calculating the average of diameter of 200 Pd nanoparticles. Pd dispersion could be obtained from average diameter of Pd particles by the following formula: D = 6 M P d ρ σ N A d × 100 % where D is Pd dispersion, MPd is the relative atomic mass of Pd (106.42 g·mol−1), ρ is the density of Pd (12.02×106 g·m−3), σ is cross sectional area of Pd atom (7.9×10− 20 m2), NA is the Avogadro constant (6.02×1023 mol−1), and d is average diameter (m) of Pd particles determined by TEM. High-angle annular dark field (HAADF) and X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) were performed by a JEM-ARM 200F scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). The samples have been reduced under 0.30 MPa of H2 at the temperature of 60°C for 30 min before test. In situ FTIR spectra of CO were recorded using a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. Around 20 mg of the catalysts was pressed into flakes and then reduced by 10%H2/Ar at 200°C for 15 min. After being cooled to room temperature, the sample was treated in Ar gas (30 mL·min−1) for 30 min. Subsequently, background spectra were collected at room temperature, after which CO (15 mL·min−1) was injected for 30 min. Finally, He gas was purged and infrared spectrum ranging from 400 ∼ 4000 cm−1 was recorded. XPS of the samples was collected using a Shimadzu Axis Supra spectrometer equipped with a Mg Kα anode. The calibration peak is C1s at 284.8 eV. The samples have been reduced under 0.30 MPa of H2 at the temperature of 60°C for 30 min before test. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) were performed on a Micrometric Chemisorb 2920 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. For the TPR, the unreduced catalysts were treated at 150°C in Ar gas flow for 30 min, followed by switching to 10% H2/Ar at room temperature and then heating to 750°C at a rate of 10°C·min−1. For the TPD, the samples were treated at 300°C in H2/Ar gas flow for 60 min, and purged with Ar for another 15 min. After cooling to 50°C. H2 was injected for 60 min at room temperature, followed by switching to Ar and heating to 700°C at a rate of 10°C·min−1. 2.6 DFT calculations The unit cell parameters of the established θ-Al2O3 model are as follow: a = 11.795 Å, b = 2.910 Å, c = 5.621 Å, α = γ = 90°, β = 103.79° and the space group is C12/m1. The (010) crystal surface was selected as the dominant exposed crystal surface for subsequent research. [15 , 16] A p (2×1) supercell was used for cell expansion, with a total of 48 O atoms and 32 Al atoms in 4 atomic layers. Adjacent slabs are separated by a vacuum zone with a thickness of 15 Å to avoid periodic interactions perpendicular to the surface. All calculations were performed using the VASP software package. [17 , 18 , 19] The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) has been adopted. [20] The k-point grids have been used (3 × 3 × 1) in the calculation of adsorption energies (E ads) and transition states (TS). The plane wave energy cutoff was set at 400 eV to achieve tight convergence. The geometric optimization converges until the force acting on the atoms was below 0.05 eV·Å−1, and the energy threshold for electron density self-consistency was set at 10−5 eV. The Climbing Image-Nuged Elastic Band (CINEB) method [21 , 22] was used to find transition states and minimum energy paths for all reactions with a force tolerance of 0.05 eV·Å−1. All saddle points identified in this work were confirmed by frequency calculations, and only one imaginary frequency was obtained at each saddle point. The E ads is defined as: E a d s = E ( s u r f + s u b s t r a t e ) − E s u r f − E s u b s t r a t e where E (surf+substrate) is the total energy of the adsorbate and the surface, E surf is the total energy of the bare surface, and E substrate is the energy of the substrate in vacuum. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Hydrogenation performance of the Pd-based catalysts modified by different elements The main reactions involved in the anthraquinone process could be seen in Fig. 1a . The catalytic performance in 2-EAQ hydrogenation of a series of modified Pd catalysts and those of other catalysts reported in literatures are listed in Table 1 . Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts exhibits much better catalytic performance towards the hydrogenation of 2-EAQ than Pd/Al2O3 catalyst and non-lanthanide (Mn, Mo, Zr, Ir, Au, Ru and Rh) doped Pd/Al2O3 catalyst under similar reaction conditions. The catalytic performance of ln-Al2O3 is conducted under the same condition, and no H2O2 could be detected by potassium permanganate titration, indicating ln-Al2O3 alone does not have the ability to hydrogenate anthraquinone. The enhancement of catalytic performance, combined with that of ln-Al2O3, confirms the remarkable synergetic effect between rare earth elements and Pd in the series of Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts. Further evaluations were conducted on Pd/Sm-Al2O3, Pd/Gd-Al2O3 and unmodified Pd/Al2O3 catalysts. The H2O2 productivity-time profiles in the 2-EAQ hydrogenation over these catalysts are shown in Fig. 1b. At 2 h, the H2O2 productivity over the Pd/Sm-Al2O3 and Pd/Gd-Al2O3 catalysts is 13.8 and 12.6 g·L−1, respectively, which is significantly higher than the figure for Pd/Al2O3 catalyst (8.4 g·L−1). The reaction order of reactants was also studied. The effect of H2 concentration on the 2-EAQ hydrogenation was determined by varying H2 pressure, since the concentration of H2 dissolved in the liquid is proportional to the H2 pressure at constant temperature (Henry's law). The results (Fig. 1c) show that the reaction order of H2 over the Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts is 0 while that of the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst is 1. In addition, catalyst performance under different concentration of 2-EAQ in the working solution was determined. As shown in Fig. 1d, the amount of produced H2O2 increased nearly linearly with the increase in EAQ concentration for all catalysts. These results indicate that the synergistic effect between rare earth elements and Pd provides enough active hydrogen on the catalyst surface to participate in hydrogenation, while the adsorption and activation of 2-EAQ remain unaffected. In order to investigate the synergistic effect and its variation with the different rare earth elements, the catalysts were characterized comprehensively. 3.2 Structural properties of Pd/ln-Al2O3 The actual contents of Pd and rare earth elements in the catalysts were determined by ICP-MS, as shown in Table 2 . The results are close to the theoretical values, which are 10.5% for Pd/Sm-Al2O3 and 10.9% for Pd/Gd-Al2O3, indicating that most of rare earth elements are successfully incorporated into the catalysts. The crystal structure of the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst and lanthanide-doped catalysts was analyzed by XRD, which was illustrated in Fig. 2 . The results show that all of the three catalysts are typical of θ-Al2O3 (JCPDS No. 35-0121), [25 , 26] although the Pd/ln-Al2O3 saw a decrease in intensity of the diffraction peaks ranging from to 31° to 40°, perhaps because the incorporation of lanthanides leads to increasing disorder of lattice fringe. Besides, no other peaks, especially those at 32.6° [27] and 56.2° [28] for PdO, 20.1° [29] for Gd2O3, and 28.3° [30] for Sm2O3, could be observed in the XRD patterns, indicating neither Pd nor rare earth elements exist as crystals. The pore structure of catalysts was characterized by low-temperature nitrogen adsorption. As shown in Fig. 3 , the adsorption-desorption isotherms of all the catalysts are type IV with a H3 hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of wedge-shaped pores in the catalysts. [31] The BET specific surface area and pore structure data of the catalysts are also listed in Table 2. The ln-modified catalysts exhibit lower specific surface area (82 ∼ 101 m2·g−1) and pore volume (0.61 ∼ 0.63 cm3·g−1), compared with Pd/Al2O3 catalyst (118 m2·g−1 and 0.79 cm3·g−1). In addition, pore size distribution illustrates that the amount of large pore is significantly reduced after the introduction of rare earth elements, possibly due to partial blockage of Al2O3 pores by rare earth elements. The 27Al MAS NMR spectrum was used to characterize the effect of rare earth elements on the Al3+ coordination structure. Fig. 4 reveals two distinct resonances at chemical shifts at approximately 8 and 63 ppm, which are indicative of the presence of Al3+ species with different coordination environments. The peak near 8 ppm can be attributed to octahedrally coordinated Al3+ species, while the broad signal centered at around 63 ppm corresponds to tetrahedrally coordinated Al3+ species. [32 , 33] The absence of the peak at around 40 ppm indicates that none of these catalysts contain pentahedral Al3+ species. [34] In addition, the relative ratio of Al3+ tetra/Al3+ octa decreases from 0.39 to 0.31 and 0.33 after incorporating the Sm and Gd, respectively, which may indicate that the two elements mainly replace Al3+ tetra and dispersed well in Al2O3. The microstructure and elemental distribution of the catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 . The Al2O3 supports have the flake structure, which is consistent with the nitrogen adsorption results. As can be seen in the Fig. 5a-c, The TEM images of the Pd/Sm-Al2O3 and Pd/Gd-Al2O3 catalysts reveal that the Pd particles have a uniform size distribution. The average diameter of Pd particles in Pd/Sm-Al2O3, Pd/Gd-Al2O3 and Pd/Al2O3 are 3.6 nm, 3.6 nm and 4.0 nm, respectively. Pd dispersion could be calculated based on average Pd particles, which is 31.0% for Pd/Sm-Al2O3 and Pd/Gd-Al2O3, and 27.9% for Pd/Al2O3. TOF of different catalysts is measured under low conversion (around 10%), and is listed in Table 1. The results show that the introduction of lanthanides could improve catalytic activity. Compared with catalysts reported in literatures, ln-doping catalysts in this work have high TOF and hydrogenation efficiency at lower temperature. The high-resolution TEM images (Fig. 5d-f) show that the particle exhibits lattice fringes with 0.23 nm, corresponding to the Pd (111) crystal plane [35]. EDS analysis in the Fig. 6 further confirms the uniform dispersion of Sm and Gd in the catalysts, consistent with the XRD and 27Al MAS NMR spectra results. The influence of rare earth elements on geometric structure and electron interaction over Pd sites was revealed by CO infrared spectroscopy, which is a common way to investigate the multi-adsorption geometries of metal nanoparticles. Fig. 7 shows the FTIR spectra of CO adsorbed on the three catalysts. There are two absorption bands at about 1965 and 1922 cm−1 over Pd/Al2O3 catalyst, which are ascribed to the vibration of bridge-bonded CO and multi-bonded CO, respectively. [36 , 37] When rare earth elements are present, the absorption band at 1922 cm−1 is blue-shifted to 1912 cm−1, showing that lanthanide-doping makes Pd NPs more electron-rich. In addition, a new absorption band at 2080 cm−1 appeared in Pd/ln-Al2O3, which can be attributed to linear adsorption of CO on Pd0. [38] It indicates that the interaction between rare earth elements and Pd leads to the appearance of isolated adsorption sites such as kinks and corners on Pd particles [39]. The XPS of the catalysts were analyzed to elucidate their chemical states and electronic properties, as can be seen in Fig. 8 and Table 3 . The Pd 3d5/2 spectrum (Fig. 8a) of the Pd/Al2O3 catalyst reveals two peaks centered at 335.4 and 337.3 eV, which correspond to metallic Pd0 and oxidized Pd2+ species, respectively. [40 , 41] The presence of Pd2+ is due to the partial oxidation of Pd particles in air. Pd2+ is easy to be reduced by hydrogen under reaction conditions and thus does not affect hydrogenation. After introducing rare earth elements into the catalysts, the BEs of Pd0 is not significantly offset. Combined with the blue shift of adsorption band in CO-FTIR spectra, these results demonstrate that doped lanthanide atoms have a limited influence on the electronic properties of all Pd atoms, and only transfer charge to their adjacent Pd atoms. The O 1s spectra (Fig. 8b) exhibit three main components located at 530.4, 531.5 and 532.8 eV, which could be attributed to lattice oxygen, adsorbed oxygen and hydroxyl oxygen species, respectively. [42 , 43] The content of hydroxyl oxygen in Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts increased with the decrease in the amount of lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen, perhaps because lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen species bonding to rare earth elements could capture H and then convert it to hydroxyl oxygen, thus promoting the transfer of active hydrogen and hydrogenation process. The Sm 3d and Gd 4d (Fig. 8c and d) indicate that both exist in +3 oxidation state. [44 , 45 , 46] The results of XPS indicate that Pd mainly exists in the form of Pd0 nanoparticles, while rare earth elements are dispersed as Sm3+ and Gd3+. In order to study the changes of reduction behavior caused by the interaction between Pd and rare earth elements, temperature programmed reduction experiments were carried out. In Fig. 9a , the negative peak around 70°C, which is present in all three catalyst samples, is attributed to the decomposition of palladium hydride to release hydrogen. [47] In addition, Sm-Al2O3 saw a reduction peak at about 650 °C, while Sm3+ could be reduced at the temperature ranging from 500 ∼ 600 °C according to literatures [48 , 49]. The temperature gap may indicate there is strong interaction between Sm3+ and Al2O3 lattice. [50 , 51] The reduction peak at 605 °C in Gd-Al2O3 could be ascribed to surface oxide of Gd3+ [52]. After impregnation, Sm3+ could be reduced at lower temperature while the reduction temperature for Gd3+ almost remained unchanged, indicating the intimacy between Pd NPs and Sm species. H2-TPD tests were carried out to investigate the ability of different catalysts to store hydrogen, which can be seen in Fig. 9b. No desorption peaks could be observed for Pd/Al2O3, indicating the undoped catalyst possesses very limited H2 storage capacity. By contrasts, both of Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts saw an obvious desorption peak centered at around 400°C, demonstrating increased H2 storage ability after ln-doping. Besides, H2 desorption completed at 500°C for Pd/Sm-Al2O3, while the temperature for Pd/Gd-Al2O3 was about 650°C, which means adsorbed H2 is easier to desorb from Pd/Sm-Al2O3. 3.3 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used to identify the role of ln sites. As shown in Fig. 10 , the activation energy (Ea) of dissociated active hydrogen (H) going through a transition state (TS) to adjacent O(-ln) sites on ln-Al2O3 support is 1.24 eV and 1.23 eV for Sm and Gd, respectively, lower than that for undoped Al2O3, at 1.78 eV. This means that H is easier to transfer from Pd to adjacent O(-ln) than O(-Al) sites. Besides, Fig. 11 shows the adsorption energies (Eads) of H at various sites on ln-Al2O3. The Eads values of H on the Al and left/right sides of O(-ln) are −0.64, −3.35, and −3.32 eV over Sm-Al2O3, and −0.68, −3.34, and −3.33 eV over Gd-Al2O3, while it is reported [14] that the figures on the Al and left/right sides of O(-Al) over Al2O3 are 2.75, −2.86, and −1.16 eV. The results show that the structure is the most stable. In addition, the Eads is significantly lower than the bond energy of the O−H bond (4.82 eV for O−H bond in water), which indicates that H is only temporarily stored at the O(-Ln) site instead of forming O−H bond. To summarize, DFT calculations indicate that H dissociated on Pd particles over the Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalyst is more easily transferred from Pd and temporarily stored at O(-ln) sites adjacent to Pd. 4 Discussion Despite H2-spillover on alumina is strictly limited, the phenomenon is much easier to happen after the introduction of lanthanides. According to DFT calculations, the adsorption energy of H on O(-ln) sites is much lower than that on O(-Al) sites. This is consistent with the H2-TPD result, where the area of desorption peak for Pd/ln-Al2O3 is higher. Both the adsorption energy and desorption peak area are similar for Sm-doped and Gd-doped catalysts, indicating nearly the same ability to store hydrogen. These results provide a thermodynamic reason for the enhanced catalytic performance of Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts. In addition, H2-TPR may shed light on the performance difference among Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts. Sm3+ could be reduced at lower temperature in Pd/Sm-Al2O3 compared with Sm-Al2O3, possibly because Sm3+ could be reduced by more spillover H that is dissociated on Pd NPs, as well as H2 adsorbed directly on Sm3+. Since this kind of spillover takes place only when Pd and lanthanide species are very close, the change in reduction temperature could reflect how intimate Pd NPs and lanthanide species are. The shorter the distance, the lower the reduction temperature of ln3+ and the better the catalytic performance, which is true according to this work and our previous study. (both the change in reduction temperature and catalytic performance are in the following order: Pd/La-Al2O3 > Pd/Sm-Al2O3 > Pd/Gd-Al2O3) [14] 5 Conclusion Several kinds of lanthanides were used to prepare Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts. TEM, HAADF-STEM, EDS and 27Al MAS NMR illustrate that lanthanides were well dispersed and replace part of Al3+ tetra. H2-TPR and H2-TPD shows that ln3+ could be reduced more easily and more H2 could be stored in Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts. DFT calculations indicate that transfer of active H needs less energy from Pd to adjacent O(-ln) sites than to Al(-O) sites, and H-O-ln structure is also more stable than H-O-Al structure. The reaction order of H2 pressure in the hydrogenation of alkylated anthraquinone decreased to 0. These findings demonstrate the universal effect of lanthanides on improving hydrogenation performance of Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts through adjacent O-(ln) sites. It not only provides an effective way to increase reaction rate of the hydrogenation of alkylated anthraquinone, but also has potential application in other hydrogenation reactions suffering from competitive adsorption among reactants. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen spillover phenomenon can significantly impact the activity in hydrogenation reaction, but the spillover is limited in a very short range on non-reducible Al2O3, a most widely used industrial support. Herein, Al2O3 doped with different lanthanides (ln) was prepared by co-precipitation, which was then used to produce Pd/ln-Al2O3 catalysts. These catalysts display much higher hydrogenation activity towards alkylated anthraquinone than undoped Pd/Al2O3 catalyst and those modified by non-lanthanide elements. After the introduction of lanthanides, the reaction order of H2 decreases from 1 to 0. Further characterization and DFT calculation show that H2 storage ability is increased for ln-doped catalysts due to the low activation energy of H transfer and low adsorption energy of H on O(-ln) sites. In addition, a reasonable relationship between reducibility of ln3+ in catalysts and the catalytic performance is found.
coredata.dc:title: Universal increase in catalytic hydrogenation performance for lanthanide-modified Pd/Al2O3 catalysts by hydrogen transfer
